intro: Hygrophila ringens subsp. longifolium, commonly known as the long-leaved hygrophila, is a species of flowering plant in the family Acanthaceae. It is native to Southeast Asia and is characterized by its slender, herbaceous stems and lance-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in wetland environments, such as marshes and along the edges of ponds. Its flowers are small, clustered in whorls, and usually have a distinctive blue or purple coloration. It is often used in aquatic gardening and as a decorative plant in water features.
